author: algaetoken
title: Sustainable Business Standards
description: There is insufficient decentralised, globally distributed and sustainable business' on the Cardano ecosystem.

f6_assessments.q0: Although it's perhaps not stated in the most clear way, this project appears to seek to create an open-sourced framework for building token-based social enterprises on the Cardano network. The social enterprise sector is a promising area to capture value creation with forward thinking innovators and people looking to disrupt traditional industries, and the research and findings of the proposers once published would potentially benefit many in the social enterprise and NGO sectors that are unsure whether to or how to develop sustainable projects on a blockchain.
f6_assessments.q1: Although it's perhaps not stated in the most clear way, this project appears to seek to create an open-sourced framework for building token-based social enterprises on the Cardano network. The social enterprise sector is a promising area to capture value creation with forward thinking innovators and people looking to disrupt traditional industries, and the research and findings of the proposers once published would potentially benefit many in the social enterprise and NGO sectors that are unsure whether to or how to develop sustainable projects on a blockchain.
f6_assessments.q2: The success of the proposal is easily auditable through the publication of the four components of the impact report.

f6_assessments.q0: This proposal has an admirable and extremely ambitious set of values as described in the SDG Rating section. The Impact statement, however, is overly vague about what it is, exactly, that the proposer is building. I wouldn't necessarily expect the proposer to present the business framework they'll be developing at this stage of the process, but I would like to see them identify the challenges and roadblocks to creating a decentralized, globally distributed, and sustainable business model, on Cardano or even just in general. At the moment the proposal does identify analyzing international regulations, which seems both necessary and insufficient. If that's to be the main focus of the project, I'd suggest zooming in on it more concisely in the Impact section.
f6_assessments.q1: The proposal presents mini-bios for three team members, two of whom are experienced microbiologists, and the third a chemical engineer with education in information systems. All three appear to have experience running and/or setting up businesses in some capacity, which looks like the type of team you'd want to assemble to tackle a framework for an environmental business model. The only reason I'm not giving the proposal five stars for Feasibility goes back to a lack of clarity regarding the scope of the project in the Impact statement. The roadmap, as presented, should be quite feasible for analyzing international regulations and identifying common denominators, but more details will help voters understand exactly what it is that this project is creating.
f6_assessments.q2: The proposal identifies reasonable deliverables in the form of impact reports but based on the roadmap outlined in the feasibility section, we won't be seeing those until the project's completion after three months. The proposer may want to consider what kinds of deliverables would be reasonable for the Month 1 and Month 2 phases of the project, even if that amounts to modest updates on the progress of research and success in acquiring the desired legal and accounting consultants.

f6_assessments.q0: Creating a new framework for others to build on will be a great idea. Something that may help this proposal is talking about what an "acceptable business standard" is in Cardano. It will be extremely important for others to learn about business standards within different blockchain ecosystems. By talking about different things such as global warming, there could be new users coming into the ecosystem for their interests. However, I don't know how important this proposal will be in the current fund. For this reason, I give 3 out of 5 stars.
f6_assessments.q1: After reading through the details on the team, I find that they will be able to successfully implement this proposal. The question is if there will be enough demand for this proposal to be funded in fund 8. The expertise is there given the years in this specific industry. For this reason, I give this section of the proposal 4 out of 5 stars.
f6_assessments.q2: There is a great amount of detail in this proposal. I enjoyed reading through the timeline/roadmap. This helps viewers to see what the proposal is striving to accomplish. The budget breakdown section was written well and it shows exactly where the potential funds would be going. This is important because it helps them to stay accountable to the community because people will be following up with them. For these reasons, I give this section of the proposal 4 out of 5 stars.

f6_assessments.q0:
The proposer has identified a problem and a solution to the problem but, the solution is presented in a general manner and it seems that it doesn't fit into the challenge brief as it is unclear what could be the open source part from this project. It is recommended to read carefully the possible directions for the Campaign and build a proposal that follow one (or more) of these.

Cryptocurrencies and their use as financial incentives are strictly regulated in many developed countries and/or even banned in others, thus making it unclear how a financial model based on cryptocurrencies could solve "climate issues/food shortage". Maybe correctly identifying the part of the Cardano ecosystem that can address these issues, a proposal with better feasibility can be created. The proposer should think at (least at) the high volatility of the cryptocurrencies market before thinking of a financial model based on tokens.
f6_assessments.q1:
There is a team presented but its members have skills and experience in areas that are not related to the blockchain technology, in generally, and with Cardano ecosystem, in particularly. Also it is unclear who are "the lawyers and accountants to allow for an efficient business model that abides by local and international laws and regulations" that are to be involved (the proposal should take into the consideration at least their number and where they can be founded) and those with international expertize are requiring more money than those at a local  (national) level.

From my perspective the plan does not take into the consideration the all resources necessary to implement the proposal. (human and non human).

There is a timetable presented with achievable milestones but some of the deliverables are presented in a vague manner and is difficult to understand them ("social impact business models that suit the Cardano ecosystem" - what is to be delivered and why is the need of Cardano ecosystem? "social enterprise options for the Cardano ecosystem" - product, solution, matchmaking? - which direction is to be followed?)

The proposer has not considered challenges and risks relevant to a successful implementation. (one of the major risks is the cryptocurrencies market high volatility thus making the financial model that supports the business model difficult to implement)
f6_assessments.q2:
Based of the info provided the proposal looks more like a concept than as a working product. In theory, a lot of business models could help reducing the carbon emissions footprint, but in the real world, businesses are driven by profit and the paths of these two concepts won't collide at a desirable impact for the humanity.

There are some defined KPI/metrics but some of them are presented in a vague manner ("Strong legal structures, both on and off chain. - is difficult to understand for any outsider what is the meaning of this sentence).

f6_assessments.q0: Building a decentralized business model canvas or framework for Cardano is a great idea, and if done correctly could bring business activity into Cardano ecosystem. It does addresses this challenge problem, which is to contribute within the open standards and interoperability within Cardano in some aspects, but I don’t see any explanation on how, or prior knowledge on why we need this business model framework other than “because it should be decentralized!”. Adding valid argument or brief explanation on why this is such an important topic to cover, would make this proposal better in informing the community. Example would be: “by allowing the Cardano community to engage and direct a decentralized open ecosystem business, it would help the traditional NGO (Non Governmental Organization, or, better known as non-profit organization) to cultivate and help with financing structure, which is currently too limiting”. Please refer to this proposal for more comprehensive example of writing the ‘impact’ aspect: https://cardano.ideascale.com/c/idea/403802
f6_assessments.q1: Although this proposal doesn’t involve in technical solution (like software engineering), the team consists of PHD and have experience with leading a company (consulting, board members, etc.) will be suitable for this project where it needs business knowledge, and conducting a research. The budget breakdown is well written and concise, which is including the work hour with salary rate for each category. The proposal also provides a conductible plan, with further description for each of them (Month 1, month 2, and month 3). Overall, a well written proposal with high chance of success, considering the planning for 3 month with the team full of researcher and relevant experience in business.
f6_assessments.q2: Roadmap is provided in detail, metrics and KPIs is explained in identifiable manner. Crucial thing to note here is where will the progress be shared? The website they provide is definitely not about this proposal, but another project with algae. Providing information about public platform to share progress is an important part, for the community to be able to track the progress.

f6_assessments.q0:
This is a passionate and well-meaning proposal that unfortunately should have been proposed in a different category and therefore receives a slightly lower impact score by me than it would have received otherwise. 
To summarize this proposal in a open standard context: an impact business based on its own token will be created and can serve as a model for others. There will be research but not implementation of a DAO. 
How do I see this in the Open Standards challenge context: this is primarily an impact business in its own right, so may have been proposed in B2C/B2B this fund instead. Hopefully, there will be Impact/Sustainability categories in the future to better accommodate proposals like this. 
Possible Open Standards angles: vendor neutral ecosystem, lower the barriers and increase open participation, collaboration across projects.
I am not entirely convinced the proposers have done enough to present their business idea in the light of its benefits to the open source or catalyst or cardano ecosystems. While the milestones have wording that suggest research is done for impact business in general, DAOs in general etc. these projects have already been done successfully (i.e. Littlefish, C4C proposals) and that the proposers plan to obtain a business license and launch their own token and impact business seems business-like and not open standard-centered. 
Therefore, I see relatively low alignment with the goals of the challenge
f6_assessments.q1:
The problem with this proposal mentioned under Impact, that it seems to be unsure whether to be a business or a template, has also created problems for its Feasibility. The proposers are all experts in the field of marine flora, algae, microbiology etc. but not experts in web3 or Cardano development. They may have proposed their business idea centered around algae as the name of their token suggests, but withhold that important information and try to lay the foundation in terms of research - presenting it as an open standards project. This suggests to me that neither is likely to succeed: for a template creating exercise, not enough web3 knowledge exists, and for a business, too much time and resources will be spent on the open standard research. It would have been much better to collaborate with other Catalyst proposers or community first and reuse existing templates or standards for their own business idea once it has matured enough to be presented here.
The budget is broken down and a timeline are provided as required, but we do not receive any concrete roadmap (meeting people, launching on testnet, providing feedback or some other output like reports, engagements, interactions).
There are not a lot of references, media or attachments to showcase the business plan or bring the project to life.
f6_assessments.q2:
The success definition of this proposal is rather vague with the main goals being strong legal structures and the acquisition of business and trading licenses. There are no numbers presented in this section and the 3 month timeline is not referred to in terms of KPIs or targets.
Some information that may have been useful for impact assessment, like the CO2-capturing properties of algae, are mentioned here, but are out of context.
I unfortunately cannot see how this proposal can be audited and it is entirely possible that it would deplete its funds without results as the targets sets are either not ambitious enough or not quantifiable.

solution: Build a decentralised sustainable business model to provide real world solutions to climate issues/food shortage connecting Cardano projects
experience: The team over 15 years’ experience in delivering sustainable environmental projects, with expertise in higher education, scientific publications, Information systems, Enterprise resource planning and project management, delivering commercial projects on a global scale.
